description:
The people of Earth were shocked to find out climate change was not a hoax. If one disaster hit them they may have been prepared, but what happens when all the disasters hit at the same time?

This Game Is A Disaster is a very uncooperative card game where each of the 2-6 players take an equal part of the deck with each card representing one of their disaster survivors. The players take turns playing cards that recreate familiar scenes from disaster movies - giant tsunamis, impromptu volcanoes, and sometimes sharks! The goal is destroy all opponents' cards and to be the last player with cards left.

A central part of "Disaster" is the shared discard pile, known as the Destroyed Pile. Players lose cards to this central pile but can play cards to retrieve as well, representing the reunions and other bright spots that appear in disaster movies.

This Game Is A Disaster is a fast and fun game that is as ridiculous as it is severe.

—description from the designer

It is storming!
Unexpected technical problems, sandbanks and the rough sea capsize the large cargo ship. The goods are discarded into the ocean and are floating onto the beach.
Curious beach combers gather on the beach.
Which beach comber collects the biggest loot?

Gameplay:
The players are rolling two special dices included in the game. The first one decides in which directions the loot is drifting: first horizontally then vertically. A small triangle marks the horizontal direction. 
The second dice decides how many steps a beach comber can move. Until loot landed on one of the sandbanks, the comber can only move horizontally. As soon as loot has stranded somewhere all combers can move directly into the direction of the loot and collect it by just moving onto the sandbank. If there are moves left, the loot can be picked up and the comber is able to move the rest of the moves back to the beach to save the goods.
A beach comber collects all goods on the sandbank which she/he landed on.

—user summary

In the flip-and-write game Fruitale, a.k.a. ãã ã‚‚ã®ãŒãŸã‚Š, the players, as fruit farm owners, grow tasty fruits and deliver them to market along with jam and honey to establish their farms.

First, two cards are flipped in the cultivation phase. Players can choose to either take the fruits shown, or take honey instead. This process continues until the full 12 weeks have been played.

In the harvest phase, players deliver their honey, sell their surplus fruits, and find out which fruits grew well enough to sell.

Finally, in the sales calculation phase, players add their scores. Whoever has sold the highest value of produce wins.

—user summary

Sea Cube is a treasure hunt game in which you seek and describe where treasures (six colored dice) lie in a box that looks like the sea. One player looks into the box through one of four periscopes and describes the locations of treasures to other players, either their team or the entire group if playing a full co-op. Teammates then mark the location and type of treasure on a map. The team with the most points wins.

Each player play the role of an agent like Jean, Bulle or WXT.
You need to play well your gadgets and purple cards to thwart the machiavellian plan of Castor. The first player to win 2 medal tokens will be the best agent and win the game.

This is a pretty clever trick taking game. On a player turn, the person who win the tricks will keep the cards on their character sheet and receive the machiavellian card which is worth points (between 1 and 6). After playing 12 hands, the winner of the round is the player with more points.

Components:
60 action cards
20 machiavellian plan cards
5 power cards
5 caracter sheets
6 medal tokens
1 rules

HOW DO YOU MAKE A GAME ABOUT THE GREAT CITIES OF ANDERSON-COTTONWOOD, CA? While it’s impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Anderson-Cottonwood we could into this box. It’s full of outdoor adventures, family attractions, rich traditions and of course...an exquisite park right in between - a little something for everybody! Looking for a fun way to experience the Shasta Cascade?

HERE’S A QUICK IDEA OF HOW TO PLAY! Buy your favorite Anderson-Cottonwood properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun! GET YOUR GAME ON!

So choose your token and advance to GO ANDERSON-COTTONWOOD! You may soon be the Mayor… or out of the game for eating too many omelets from Becca’s Café! THIS IS ANDERSON-COTTONWOOD.... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

-description from designer

HOW DO YOU MAKE A GAME ABOUT THE GREAT CITY OF CRESCENT CITY, CA? While it’s impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Crescent City we could into this box. It’s full of outdoor adventures, family attractions, rich traditions and of course...an old, historic lighthouse - a little something for everybody! Looking for a fun way to experience Land’s End?

HERE’S A QUICK IDEA OF HOW TO PLAY! Buy your favorite Crescent City properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun! GET YOUR GAME ON!

So choose your token and advance to GO CRESCENT CITY! You may soon be the Mayor… or out of the game for eating too many pizzas from SeaQuake Brewing! THIS IS CRESCENT CITY.... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

-description from designer

The Barracks Emperors is a strategy card game set against the backdrop of the Roman Crisis of the Third Century, during which at least 45 different men made a claim to the throne of the Roman Empire.  In this game, 1-4 players represent prominent political factions attempting to gain control over the men who would be Emperors of Rome.  Players deploy the influence available to them (represented by the cards in their hands) to claim imperial reigns (represented by the historical Emperor cards arrayed on the board.)   But they must be very careful, because politics is a complex game, and sometimes attempting to exert your influence necessitates aiding someone else in their own plots.  Play your cards cleverly to capture Emperors and score the most points to win.

At its heart, The Barracks Emperors is a trick-taking game, but not one like you’ve ever seen before. In this innovative design, all 13 tricks are available for play simultaneously, in an interlocking grid that forces you to balance the value of every card you play against the value that same card may have for another player on a different trick.  Plus, every card grants you an additional special ability that you might be able to use to spring a surprise on your unwitting opponents.

Features:
Historical emperors, co-emperors, pretenders, and even Gallic Emperors who broke away from Rome during the Crisis of the Third Century are all represented as individual cards in the game, each with interesting facts about the rise and demise of the man depicted.

For fans of Time of Crisis: The Roman Empire in Turmoil, 235-284 AD and Time of Crisis: The Age of Iron and Rust, you will find some of the concepts and flavor from that deck-building wargame, adapted in this all new standalone game.  You don’t need Time of Crisis to play The Barracks Emperors, but you’ll recognize Influence Cards such as Praetorian Guard, Foederati, and Pretender, now used in an entirely new way.

An innovative card drafting mechanic adds an extra layer of strategy to how you play your cards while also mitigating the luck that would come with being dealt a full hand of cards at the start of each round.

This game is designed for 4 players, but also includes options for 2 or 3 players, plus an easy-to-play solitaire adaptation for the solo player.

Publisher's summary
ã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚­ã‚’ã¤ãã‚ã† (KÄ“ki o tsukurou) (Let's Make A Cake) is a children's game from Japan.

Players bake some cakes, and the player who bakes the most delicious cake is the winner. A delicious cake is one that either has all the same fruit on the cake, or all different fruits on the cake.

Players pick fruits from a bag and put them on their cakes. When putting fruit on the cake, you should look at the cakes the other players are making. You can try to work out which fruits are more likely to come out of the bag, by seeing what has already been made. This will help you win!

This game is made for children from 6 years up, younger children can play if someone helps with the scoring. In fact, even five-year-olds were playing in the test play, it was very exciting.

The name of this Swedish film trivia game translates as "Let's go to the videos". Released by a Swedish video distribution company in collaboration with Target Games, it may have been used in some promotional context, but the game itself doesn't contain any specific promotional material.

Gameplay consists mostly of answering trivia questions about films or TV shows, or related topics such as actors or source material. Each question card has questions at three nominal difficulty levels, and answering a question correctly allows a player to move along a track towards the goal by rolling a 4-, 6- or 8-sided die. Some spaces mean a player instead has to mime a movie title for the other players to guess.

—user summary

Players get dealt 4 musicians and instruments to form a band. Each player has 2 actions they can take on a turn 1) play a card 2) Trash (discard) one of their instruments. As the bands battle it out to win over the crowd, their ultimate goal is to impress the Record Label Scout who is attending the show. At the start of each game, a label scout is chosen at random and placed on the table. Each label scout has different victory conditions and the first band to meet one of the conditions wins.

-description from designer

10 famiglie is a game with 40 cards representing 10 families (father, mother, son and daughter) and 10 hourglasses.
It reimplements classic card games like Go fish/Happy family and Tappo.
The first game is played with the family cards and has the same rules of Go fish.
The second is a cooperative game using also the hourglasses. Player have to complete the 10 families, playing them on the board from 1 to 4, before drawing the 10 hourglasses.
The third game is like Tappo: each player has 4 cards and, drafting them with the other players, tries to complete a family.

—description from the designer

Unico is a game with 66 cards, based on the traditional game Crazy eights.

Everyone gets 5 cards and must play a matching card (colour or animal/number): if they haven't a matching card, pick up 1 from the stock pile.
In the basic version there the following special cards:

     chameleon: you can play it when you want, like a joker.
     crab: play clockwise/counter-clockwise order.
     kangaroo: the next player misses his turn.


In the advanced version, there also these special cards:

     snake: you can exchange one card with another player.
     hands: all player put their hand on this card. The last player draws 2 cards.


The first player to discard all their cards wins.

—description from the publisher

The very word “Malyava” represents a "Kite" which is a prison`s slang for a small letter, sent by one prisoner to another or to outer mates, via secret ways.

The Game for three to six gamblers will create a fun atmosphere and light up your party. This is the multiplayer strategic based Game with rich visuals inspired by the Russian prison subculture.

Each gamer will assume the role of a Cop (Guard), a Con (Inmate) or a Kingpin (Prison Boss). Buying and playing the “Lousy life” cards, participants earn money and interact with other players. The goal of the Game is to move according to the Map and to be the first to reach freedom. You must solve a number of interesting tasks: such as writing an encrypted letter to a cellmate, keeping in mind that the Cop is hunting for it.

Should you get trapped – you must perform various funny or extravagant tasks. Who will win? One of the cons who achieved freedom or cop prevented escape? May luck smile up on you!

This restaurant deck plays the same as the original Lord of the Fries, but with ingredients and menu themed as a Mexican restaurant.  Ingredients in this deck include Rice, Tortillas, Beans, 'Red Stuff', 'Green Stuff', Cheese, Bird, Cow and Pig.

Special Rule: You may substitute any type of meat for the correct meat, but played for zero points (play the card face down).

Besides being an expansion to Lord of the Fries, this can be played as a stand alone.
—user summary

Zombies Making Food.
That's the idea behind Lord of the Fries.
You and your friends are a crew of not-so-smart Zombies, racing to assemble meals from hands of random ingredients.
It's a simple, fast, and funny card game for you and all your no-so-smart friends.
This deck can be played by itself or mixed with others.
You need a 6-sided die to play this game.
—description from the back of the box

Almanac: The Crystal Peaks is a game of trade, travel, and adventure through a whimsical fantasy realm! Players will visit strange places, acquire and sell goods, and face an unpredictable set of encounters as they travel from the Trader's Village to either High Frost, the seat of power in the region, or Two Twins City, the center of commerce! In Almanac: The Crystal Peaks, adventure and riches are just a turn of the page away!

Almanac: The Crystal Peaks is the second entry in the Almanac series of games from acclaimed designer Scott Almes. Each round of Almanac is played on a different page in the gamebook. Each page represents a unique location/board with a special twist on worker placement. When combined an innovative bidding mechanism for turn order and a vast array of fantasy encounters, every game of Almanac: The Crystal Peaks is a new experience!

—description from the publisher

Rollecate is about a historic steam locomotive, built in 1967 by a famous Dutch engineer. It's been sitting in storage for the past five years and is eager to get rolling again — and the players of this game will make that happen!

In this smart and innovative tile-laying game, players build new tracks for Rollecate to ride on. But Rollecate is very eager and can't wait to roll, turning this game into an exciting race against the clock. Causing Rollecate to derail is costly, so players have to try to avoid that.

This game combines tile laying, press-your-luck dice rolling, and tactical set building mechanisms into a swift game that is fun to play for all kinds of players.

The game consists of 55 playing cards, four custom dice, and a wooden train figure. The Kickstarter edition instead contains a scale 1:87 white metal miniature locomotive.

—description from the designer

Explore the historic city of George Town, Penang! 'Kaki lima' is the Malay term for five-foot way - the arched pathways that line the heritage zone of a tropical island in northern Malaysia. Play as pedestrians navigating their way through a grid of kaki lima. Score victory points from reaching places on daily task lists, exploring cultural sites, and meeting up with other pedestrians to taste local delicacies. Walking being at the heart of the game, points are also scored for clearing blocked kaki lima to make a more accessible neighbourhood.

—description from the designer

The head of the city's most powerful organized crime family is dead. Other less-influential families seize the opportunity to grab a bigger piece of the action by whatever means necessary. As the head of one of these families, you seek ways to twist the workings of the city towards your own interests. Politicians, police, the news, and even other family members are all necessary tools.

During HIT!, you play cards which represent your family's fight for control across the city. Each round you compete to make the stronger power grab without exceeding that round's Influence Limit, which is set by each player initially playing one card face-down to the middle of the table. You may not know the exact value, but careful observation of your opponent's play could reveal more than they are letting on.

HIT! consists of a deck of 32 cards valued 1 through 8 (4x) and four player tokens. Some cards describe effects that occur when the card is revealed during play.

—description from the designer

A tactical board game where you play against other plays to conquer a new world by gaining the most influence over it. Influence is achieved through a combination of warfare, knowledge, money and religion, allowing players to each adopt different strategies to win.

In turns players can choose to explore unsettled territory, attack opponents or pursue religious, knowledge or cultural growth through a variety of research. As players develop, they can increase influence points with the first player to  reach 20 points claiming ultimate victory.

The game can be played individually with others or in teams, allowing for many different ways of playing.

—description from the designer

In all the Holds of Men, one is first among equals. . .Hawkshold.

No feudal duke, nor Elven prince, nor Dwarven lord marches to war without knowing how Hawkshold will respond.  The Grand Duke of Hawkshold can field legions of brave knights, trained soldiers, and ruthless mercenaries.

The Men of Hawkshold is a reprinting of the very first faction of Battleground Fantasy Warfare, featuring redesigned rules and all new artwork.

Battleground Fantasy Warfare is a miniatures game — without miniatures! Units are represented by cards portraying the warriors and their characteristics. Each player builds their army, deploy their units, and assigns them orders. Once the battle begins, each player only has a limited ability to command their army. The player with the better plan can use their commands to inspire or enchant their units in combat.

Quick to set up, easy to store, Battleground is a game that can be played at your kitchen table and carried in your pocket. And yet Battleground is a deeply tactical game, where maneuver and marshaling your limited command resources are the keys to victory.

In this card and dice game you play as a group of select beings capable of traversing different planes as you need to battle it out not only for your survival, but that of mankind.

Each player starts off by selecting a plane walker from the deck and then a landscape from the plane deck. The landscape will come with a preset effect which alters each players abilities  as well as default dice rolls. A set of dice is then rolled by each of the players and combined to form combinations which enable a player to make different moves against their opponent. Every round a new landscape is drawn, so players will need to adjust their tactics per landscape.

The first player to have thief life points reduced to 0 ultimately loses the game. The game can be played with either one or multiple plan walkers per player, depending on length of game that is desired.

—description from designer

Ronin of the Reach is a fast-paced card game for 2-6 space pilots with 10 minutes to spare.

In Ronin of the Reach your dexterity is as important as your tactical skills.
Maneuver by carefully flicking your ship card across the battle field.
Avoid hazards such as asteroids, space mines or the debris of an unlucky player´s ship.
Choose one of your six hand cards and place it face down next to your craft.
Pick an offence or a defense action. For each weapon there is a matching counter measure.
But think ahead! You can play every action just once. Anticipate your enemy’s move or waste precious cards.
Every ship is equipped with a onetime secret ability. Played at the right moment, nasty surprises like advanced railguns, cloaking devices and military viruses can tip the tide of battle to your favor.
So, choose the moment carefully.
Expand your experience by adding capital ships to Ronin of the Reach. Team up with your wing man and destroy the other team’s flagship. Switch action cards with your team mate to adapt your tactics on the fly.
But don’t forget to place defenses on your own capital ship.

Ronin of the Reach is the perfect starter for your board game evening. Quick set up - fast to play and easy to learn.

—description from the publisher

"The intergalactic symbols of kosmic peace have been scattered across the meow-tiverse! Fearless, intrepid Kosmic Kittens have spread far and wide to collect them! It's your job to bring these symbols together, restore order and peace to existence and gain a better Kosmic score than all the other Kittens in the game!"

Kosmic Kittens is a purr-fectly fun pair matching card game for all feline fans across the meow-tiverse!
Swap cards with your neighbour
Match up pairs of symbols to score points

Use special power cards to improve your game

When all the pairs are matched, the winner is the kitty with the most points!

But beware of the Space Hound! If you finish with this dastardly mutt you’ll loose ten points!
Kosmic Kittens is a purr-fectly fun pair matching card game for all feline fans across the meow-tiverse!

—description from the designer

The river is filled with otters of all shapes and sizes. Decide which otter should jump into the river at the right time to maximize your score. Having the winning otter gets you more cards, but losing lets you pick the scoring conditions.

Why I otter.....

—description from the designer


SETUP

Deal a hand of 3 card to each player. Place the rest of the cards face-down (river-side up) in a pile.

GAMEPLAY

Each round players will create the river, jump in, and then distribute the rewards.

1) Create the river
Draw the top 3 cards out onto the table (river-side up) in a line to show the river.

2)Jump In
First player plays a card from his hand face-up (otter-side up). Then their opponent must play a card face-up. Both cards are assessed (rock-paper-scissors mechanic) to see which player wins the round. Higher card number breaks ties.

3) Collect rewards

The round winner does the following:

     They take the two otter cards into their den. Your den is a face-up line of the otters you've won. This will be used for endgame scoring.
     They choose one of the three cards from the river to take into their hand.


The round loser does the following:

     They choose from the remaining two river cards and decide which will go into their hand and which will become and endgame scoring card. Place the scoring cards into a column showing the scoring conditions. At the end of the game, both players will score off of all  the scoring cards.


The winner of the round goes first in the next round. Rounds continue until both players have no more cards in hand.

END OF GAME

After each player has played all of their otters, score the otters in your den according to the scoring conditions on the four river cards. Highest score wins!


Released in the February 2019 Board Game of the Month Club $20+ package.

Get ready for tank battles! In the board game World of Tanks: Winners,  each player will have a hangar with equipment, and you will have to compete with your rivals in accuracy, speed and combat power. Lightning solutions and accurate calculation will lead you to a sure victory!

Winners consist of a deck of cards that are equally distributed to all players. Unfolded cards lie in front of players in stacks, face down. Then one of them opens the top card in his pile and looks at the parameters of the tanks indicated in its upper part.
The player announces what parameter the competition will take: mass, power, speed or shooting, after which all other players open the top card from their piles. The one from whom the chosen parameter will be maximized takes the opened cards to himself, puts them under the bottom of his stack and makes the following move: he opens the card and chooses the parameter by which the tanks compete.
The game ends at the moment when one of the players runs out of cards. The winner is the one who has the most cards in the pile. In the rules there is also the option of a long game, when the game ends only when there is only one player left with the cards.
The kit includes a promo card of the Soviet T-54 tank for World of Tanks: Rush.

Tai-Chi, Wu-Dang, Wing-Chun, Shao-Lin, and all those spectacular Kung Fu factions gather together today. Will you be the last one standing to claim the title of Kung Fu Master?

Kung Fu is a dice-driven card game for 2-5 players to compete for the title of Kung Fu Master. After drafting 10 Kung Fu cards and adjusting the initial status, each player will play 3 cards from their hand simultaneously for each round. Based on the overall initiative values, players will take turns to be the attacker while all the others must defend for themselves. During the fight, each player rolls their own 7 dice and assign them in sets to activate their three Kung Fu cards to attack or defend.

The game ends when there is only one player standing, or after three rounds, the player with the most HP remaining wins!

Tatorship is a card game, where you assume the role of Tators who back stab, bluff and ultimately break down democracy. Learn the method applied historically to identify that behavior in the future!

Tators react to events to gain political influence, and can either pass laws or campaign to become the Executive! In this fast paced card game you either gain resources or back stab cards, so there will never be a dull moment!

The game ends after the first player gets 5 Tatorpoints, gained by removing Supreme Judges and eventually Basic Rights.

—description from the designer
A Board/Trivia game based on the Moët et Chandon Champagne world.  Questions are about History/Tourism, economy/gastronomy, and viniculture.  Board represents the Champagne area.

Mercenaries who came to plunder forgotten treasures, you woke up the Octoman. You'll have to run fast not to be devoured!
To survive: manage your weapons to the best of your abilitiy, give your treasures up if you need to and lure the Octoman onto your companions of misfortune!

A game of OctoRage takes place in several rounds. 
As soon as a player wins 2 rounds, he wins the game.
During their turn, players will be able to play a:

     Weapon card, whose value must be greater or equal to the last card played. If the card is an 8, then the Octoman's rage is increased by 1.
     Dodge card, which changes the direction of the turn.
     Treasure card, which curses another player and decreases his chances of survival.


If a player can't or does not want to play a card, then he is attacked by the Octoman. He loses as many tokens of life as the Rage value of the Octoman.
If a player loses his last token of life, then he is eliminated.
A round ends when only one player remains alive.

—description from designer

No DRAW is an abstract tiles placement game based on the classic “Tic-tac-toe”.

The purpose is to compose the largest number of tic tac toe with the tiles on which it’s indicated a numeric value and carry the highest score.
The players have also some action tiles that influence the course of the game, so that the challenges can get more dynamic.
Round after round, the players can modify their strategy deciding whether to collect points or hinder the opponent.
NO DRAW is simple, intuitive and quick to learn.
Game after game, it will give you and your friends hours of fun.

—description from the designer

A simple, enjoyable and fun set of Planetary Ground Combat Wargames Rules for micro scale models or counters. The rules form the first part of a trilogy called Star Command.

Included in the download is a rules booklet, a front cover and 40 game cards. No dice are required for playing the game; the game cards will determine any chance or damage results. Card vehicle counters will be available from our website soon as a free download, so all you really need to play the game is your trusty ruler.

Starforce Command is set in the future after your home world has been under alien domination for nearly a millennium. The planetary resistance has successfully struck against the aliens, unleashing a deadly virus that has annihilated the unwanted creatures. But from the blackened ashes of disaster Star Command was born, a military organisation that used the aliens’ technology against them. For over two millennium war as raged unceasingly across the known universe.

Design your own Starforce in a matter of minutes with the use of the free vehicle design sheet, then select your grunt squads and go forth to victory. Land your Starforce with drop ships or appear through jump gates ready to assault your foe. Draw specially designed game cards to determine your random chance, and then use the same cards to inflict damage upon your enemy. Modify and redesign your vehicles if they don’t just fit the role, fine tune them and try again, seek perfection and you might just get the ultimate Starforce.

—description from publisher

In this version, questions are prepared by players.
It seems easy to mention three uses for your tongue - but can you do it in 5 seconds when you just mess up your tongue? The rest of the players are watching you, waiting impatiently for your response, and time is running out! Just throw it away!

å››å­£æŠ˜æŠ˜ ("Humble Tea Party") is a set collection game featuring Japanese confectionary tiles. Tiles are arranged in a 3x3 grid, and points may be earned by aligning different symbols on the cards vertically, horizontally, or diagonally.

However, the goal is to maximize the score of others, not yourself. But, it is a non-co-op game, and there is only one winner.

Each player also has a hidden "favorite season" with players attempting to hide certain tiles because they will earn high scores if they place "favorite season" sweets in their box.

—user summary

Idols, athletes, performers, musicians, politicians: the celebrities in this seemingly glamorous place have shadowy sides that people can not see. If you sell such gossip material to a weekly magazine, or to the person, it will be a big deal.

In ã‚´ã‚·ãƒƒãƒ—ã‚¢ãƒ³ãƒ‰ã‚¶ã‚·ãƒ†ã‚£ (Gossip and the City), the players are freelance reporters and collect celebrity gossip while also exchanging gossip with other players.

The lead player flips cards from a deck and other players make an offer of cards to exchange for the flipped cards.  The lead player chooses one of the offers and takes those cards.  However, there is an incentive not to flip too many cards.

The players will earn points based on the number of icons for each color collected, but this score is also affected by the numerical sum of the cards of that color collected.

The circus is a nasty business. There are people to pay, animals to take care of, messes to clean, accidents to fix... and that's before you've even put on the show!

9-Card Circus is an in-hand resource management game for 1 player. Over the course of 4 years, you will work to make the best circus you can by rotating, flipping, and re-arranging cards. If you're careless, however, you'll be forced to start over from scratch, as your reckless management draws public ire and government regulations.

Every decision has consequences, and you'll need to think multiple turns ahead to ensure success. With deep, interesting mechanics, a lack of reliance on memory, and a small footprint, 9-Card Circus is a game you can take and play anywhere.

9-Card Circus also has a series of campaign challenges, which each modify a rule of the game and force you to change your strategy in order to succeed.

—description from the designer

Saloon Shootout is a mini-tactics game, using only 9 cards and a few dice. You'll need to rely on your wits, your strategy, and your luck to survive.

In Saloon Shootout, you control a team of outlaws who have been surrounded by a rival gang. Your team is severely wounded, and will bleed out quickly unless you can survive the onslaught of knives and bullets headed your way.

Each turn, you move your teammates around a randomly-generated saloon, taking cover from enemy units while trying to take them down. Each character has their own unique attributes and abilities, which you'll need to take advantage of in order to survive.

Featuring interesting tactical gameplay, a unique map-building mechanic, and dozens of team composition, Saloon Shootout is a must if you're interested in games like Imperial Assault or XCOM.

—description from the designer

Learning 'times' tables is dull but necessary.  Tableland makes it fun.  Tableland is a unique game devised by Professor Dexter Dunphy of the University of N.S.W. to help his own children enjoy learning their tables.  For ages 6 to 10.

In turn, each player rolls a die and moves their token around the board.  At crossroads the player can decide for themselves which track to take.  If the player lands on a Multiplication space, the player has to give the correct answer or go back to where their have come from.  If another player thinks the answer given is wrong, they may 'challenge'. If the challenger is correct they will gain bonus spaces.

If a player lands on a purple space they will receive some advantage; if the player lands on a red space they will receive a disadvantage.  First player to the finish space wins.

—user summary

Zerywia is a cooperative adventure board game set in the primeval world of Slavic myths. It includes a campaign mode composed of individual adventures for 1 to 4 players, linked together by an overarching storyline. Each adventure can also be played separately, as standalone episodes. This enables the players to experience each story in different ways and allows to lead their Heroes on a different path during each playthrough.

Each Hero has their own Saga, a tale waiting to be uncovered and told. Progressing through it grants powerful, new relicts, rituals or allies. As they roam the lands, the Heroes will be able to acquire new Sagas, which shall give them more power and unlock new, hitherto hidden parts of the story. This is why our Heroes are a work in progress, so to speak, and it falls upon the players to shape them and lead them to noble (or not quite so) deeds.

—description from the publisher

Every year, magicians from around the world come to the MAGICOA Grand Market to buy new magic potions.

     Try to buy the best magic potions available using your gold coins by bidding
     Accumulate magic points or use your potions to activate powers
     You'll have to use cunning and mischief to win the most coveted potions and become the most powerful magician!

Your goal is to reach the end of the year, of course this is not an easy task. Pickets, fines, taxes, protests, corralitos, looting, devaluations and other endless problems will be presented to you every day. But now let's talk about the game ... Well, it's similar, only much more fun and it will also help you see reality in a different way. To achieve your mission you have 5,000 pesos in your pocket, 5 cards and a chain of businesses ready to open.

On your turn, you must choose one of the following options:
a) Advance, as many boxes as the dice indicate.
b) Charge, the State will pay you 100 times what the dice say (and well, it's a game!).
c) Draw a card.

There are three kinds of cards: problems, solutions and bonds. With the problems, you can stop the other players by devaluating them, fining them, looting them or corralling their money. With the solutions, you can solve the problems that your competitors threw at you (but unfortunately these solutions only work in the game). With the bonds (and this may be strange for everyone) you can take advantage of their value and exchange them with the state for money.

On your way to the end of the year, you will land on empty lots where you can put your business, listen to the National Chain, collect privilege pensions, pay extraordinary taxes, sell pots and many other things that will make you think that you have always been a great player of this game and that nobody else will be able to win.

This game references the 1998-2002 Argentine Great Depression.

—description from the translated

Su objetivo es llegar a fin de año, claro que esto no es tarea fácil. Piquetes, multas, impuestos, cacerolazos, corralitos, saqueos, devaluaciones y otro sinfín de problemas se le presentarán día a día. Pero ahora hablemos del juego… Bueno, es parecido, sólo que mucho más divertido y además le ayudará a ver la realidad de otra manera. Para lograr su cometido Usted cuenta con 5.000 pesos en el bolsillo, 5 tarjetas y una cadena de negocios lista para abrir.

En su turno, Usted debe optar por una de las siguientes opciones:
a)    Avanzar, tantas casillas como indiquen los dados.
b)    Cobrar, el Estado le pagará 100 veces lo que dicen los dados (¡y bueno, es un juego!).
c)    Levantar una targeta.

Hay tres clases de tarjetas: problemas, soluciones y bonos. Con los problemas, Usted puede frenar a los otros jugadores devaluándolos, multándolos, saqueándolos o acorralándoles el dinero. Con las soluciones, Usted puede resolver los problemas que sus competidores le arrojaron a Usted (pero lamentablemente estas soluciones sólo sirven para el juego). Con los bonos (y esto puede ser extraño para todos) Usted puede aprovechar su valor y cambiarlos al Estado por plata.

En su recorrido hasta fin de año, Usted caerá en lotes vacíos donde podrá poner sus negocios, escuchará la Cadena Nacional, podrá cobrar jubilaciones de privilegio, pagar impuestos extraordinarios, vender cacerolas y muchas otras cosas que le harán pensar que Usted siempre ha sido un gran jugador de este juego y que nadie le va a poder ganar.

Este juego hace referencia a la Gran Depresión Argentina 1998-2002.

—description from the publisher

Players are given one set of colored cards, either all reds or all blacks. Players are also given one different colored King. To win the game, you have to find your colored king in your opponent's deck. Players lay their full deck face down, choosing which cards go where. Players take turns choosing which cards move around and which ones fight, with highest number winning. Don't loose track of the king, because if you accidentally expose him, you lose!

—description from the publisher

In Ogre Under, each player controls a merchant and a donkey who are transporting goods across an ogre-infested bridge, headed for the market in the city. In each round, players select an action card from their hand and then simultaneously reveal them. Action cards allow players to perform one of the following actions:


     Flip over one of the eight bridge cards, potentially revealing an ogre that scares any merchants and donkeys on that card backwards a number of spaces.
     Protect their merchant from a possible ogre attack.
     Move their donkey forward, up to their merchant's current location.
     Bet on whether the next market price card to be revealed will be higher or lower than the current one. Correct bets move your merchant forward a number of spaces (based on how risky the bet was), while incorrect bets move your merchant back to your donkey's current location. 


Play continues round after round until one or more players win by having both their merchant and their donkey in the city market at the end of a round.

Read My Mind is the game of clues and creative connections.

In this game like minds battle rapid thinkers. Write your own ending to a given statement, then try to communicate it to just one other player.

Beware! Your opponents will try to second-guess you and grab your points. Can you get your message across without being robbed by rivals? Can you hijack their efforts and add to your score? Think fast, think smart to make the connection - and don't get lost for words!

The winner is the first to reach the target score. You win points by getting a nominated opponent to be the only player to guess the answer you have devised, or by being first to correctly guess the answer another opponent has devised.

—description from the designer
A satirical game where the male army represented by bolts, tries to keep the female army, represented by the brass rings, in the kitchen.

Connections is based on a tested and proven psychological theory known in clinical circles as "Choice Theory".  This game allows players to enjoy the benefits and to learn the psychological lessons of the theory without ever having to crack a book, attend a lecture, or lie on the couch.

—description from the publisher

During the game, players roll and move around the board.  Along the way, they will encounter cards for Connecting Habits, Disconnecting Habits, and Quality World.  Upon giving personal answers to these cards, players will earn points.  The first player to reach 1,000 points wins.

The box contains: board, D6, six player pawns, 33 game cards, 6 escape cards, beginner's guide, score pad, and instructions.

—user summary
